comments.body: here also, I think we must switch back to the graph stage threads with the asyncCallback. This however changed the amount of reconnects in the test.
Since it is future-based, I'm not to worried about switching back. But this also works. Thanks!
Here also, just simplified some code

The epoch is used to track whether the producer is stale; on each disconnect, the epoch is incremented. By remembering the creation epoch, old producers can be discarded once the in-flight message lands.
Replaced with Akka library call providing the same functionality.
`withReconnect` is set to `false` for the publisher at this point, until we can be certain reconnects behaving correctly with the publisher. Then even the `if` block below can be taken out.

why not just
```scala
          val delay = waitTime(nextN).min(maxBackoff)
          after(delay, system.scheduler) {
            openConnectionWithRetry(startConnection, nextN)
          }
```
? :)

Since `waitTime` is an exponential function, there is a very small chance a very large backoff may overflow, throwing this logic into haywire. That's why I really want to stop calculating the `waitTime` after max is reached.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +31,35 @@  protected val fail: AsyncCallback[Throwable] = getAsyncCallback[Throwable](e => failStage(e))

  private val onConnection: AsyncCallback[jms.Connection] = getAsyncCallback[jms.Connection] { c =>
    jmsConnection = Some(c)
  }

comments.body: Great to keep the `jms` prefix to distinguish things.
If the properties contain a value which is not of any of these types, would it make sense to explicitly throw an exception instead of the default MatchError?

In general, I would say yes.

However, the Jms producer crashes on any exception, and does not distinguish between retriable errors and non-retriable ones - it doesn't perform any retries. So in the end, the behavior would still be very similar if we introduced a custom exception here. It would make much more sense to introduce a custom exception if the Jms producer stage did retries, and would not try to do those retries if the property value type is of an unexpected type.

(please note:  this is part of the code I moved out of the stage into a separate class - I didn't modify it)

@WellingR after giving it some thought, those exceptions can be handy in supervision logic too, so here is a proposal - what do you think? https://github.com/akka/alpakka/pull/1148/commits/a2805765cdd09868f878f2d514788d1914d984b1

Looks better!
I had some comments about the exception traits though.
